L1.brief_rationale: The broad discipline applying scientific methods to legal questions; universally recognized through popular media and general education as the foundation of crime investigation.
The fundamental archaeological field method of systematic digging; known to any educated person as the core activity of archaeology.
Any object made or modified by humans recovered from an archaeological context; universally recognized term requiring no specialized training.
The bony framework of the human body; universally known and central to forensic-archaeological work involving human remains.
Genetic material used to identify individuals; widely known through media coverage of criminal trials and is a cornerstone concept for any newcomer to forensic science.
The location where a crime occurred and evidence is collected; universally understood term foundational to all forensic disciplines.
The interment of human remains; a concept encountered in everyday culture, history, and religion that is the primary subject of forensic-archaeological investigation.
The most widely known scientific dating technique; recognized by any educated person as a method for determining the age of organic materials.
A burial site containing multiple victims, often associated with atrocities or disasters; a concept familiar from news media and historical events.
The ethical and legal framework underpinning international forensic investigations into war crimes and atrocities; universally recognized as a foundational concept.
Violations of international humanitarian law that forensic archaeologists frequently investigate; widely known through coverage of international tribunals and conflicts.
Material or information used to establish facts in legal proceedings; a universally understood concept that links archaeology to the legal system.
The principle that older layers lie beneath younger ones; a basic archaeological concept introduced in any introductory course and widely encountered in popular science.

L2.brief_rationale: The study of how organisms decay and become preserved; essential forensic-archaeology vocabulary that students encounter early in bioarchaeology and forensic osteology courses.
The scientific study of bones; core technical vocabulary for any student of forensic archaeology or physical anthropology dealing with skeletal remains.
The precise documented findspot of an artifact or bone within an excavation; a key field-methodology term that distinguishes student-level knowledge from lay understanding.
The documented sequence of possession of evidence ensuring its legal admissibility; a standard forensic term that students must understand to work in medico-legal contexts.
The application of physical anthropology to legal questions, principally skeletal analysis; the closest disciplinary neighbor of forensic archaeology and standard student vocabulary.
The estimation of age, sex, ancestry, and stature from skeletal remains; a foundational concept for students learning skeletal analysis in forensic contexts.
Systematic inspection of the ground surface and subsurface to locate archaeological features; a standard field method that students of forensic archaeology must master.
The biological and chemical breakdown of organic tissue after death; a core concept linking taphonomy to time-of-death estimation in forensic contexts.
The spatial and stratigraphic relationship of a find to its surroundings; a technical term critical for students understanding how forensic evidence is recorded.
The elapsed time between death and discovery of remains; a key forensic concept students encounter in both medicolegal and archaeological contexts.
The recovery of previously buried remains for forensic or legal purposes; a central operational term for forensic archaeologists working on human rights and criminal cases.
A diagrammatic tool for recording stratigraphic relationships between excavated units; standard student-level field methodology taught in all archaeology programs.
The use of insect succession patterns to estimate postmortem interval and circumstances of death; important cross-disciplinary vocabulary for forensic archaeology students.

L3.brief_rationale: Analysis of ratios of stable isotopes in bone and teeth to reconstruct diet, geographic origin, and migration; requires working knowledge of geochemistry applied to skeletal material.
A non-invasive geophysical technique used to detect subsurface anomalies such as clandestine graves; requires practical understanding of remote sensing in forensic fieldwork.
Skeletal injuries that occurred and showed healing before death, distinguishable from perimortem and postmortem damage; requires working knowledge of bone biology and fracture classification.
An illegally concealed burial site, the primary search target in criminal and human-rights investigations; requires applied knowledge of search methodology and site detection techniques.
Systematic interpretation of fractures, cut marks, and other injuries on bone to determine cause and manner of death; requires working expertise in both osteology and pathology.
Skeletal elements from multiple individuals mixed together in a single deposit; requires working knowledge of sorting, minimum number of individuals calculation, and DNA-aided reassociation.
The use of overlapping photographs to generate accurate 3-D models of excavated features and remains; an increasingly standard documentation technique requiring technical competence.
Pre-death dental records used to establish positive identification of skeletal remains; requires working knowledge of forensic odontology and victim identification protocols.
The systematic recording of a forensic scene through photography, mapping, and note-taking before and during excavation; requires applied knowledge of evidence preservation standards.
Optically or thermally stimulated luminescence methods for dating sediments surrounding buried remains; requires working knowledge of geoarchaeological dating methods beyond radiocarbon.
International standards for identifying victims of mass disasters using primary and secondary identifiers; requires working knowledge of multi-agency forensic identification systems.
Plant material, pollen, seeds, and wood recovered from forensic scenes used to reconstruct environment and postmortem interval; requires applied botanical and taphonomic knowledge.

L4.brief_rationale: The differentiation of fractures sustained around the time of death from those produced after skeletonization, based on bone hydration and fracture morphology; requires expert-level biomechanical and taphonomic understanding.

Microscopic and macroscopic identification of tool-inflicted striations on bone to determine weapon type, direction of force, and dismemberment patterns; requires expert reading of bone surface modification.

The layer-by-layer removal and recording of burial fills following stratigraphic principles in medico-legal contexts, adhering to court-admissible standards; requires deep integration of archaeological method with legal procedure.

A statistical estimate of the fewest individuals that could account for all skeletal elements in a commingled assemblage; requires expert knowledge of skeletal anatomy and quantitative analytical methods.
Matching strontium-87/86 ratios in tooth enamel to bedrock maps to pinpoint geographic origin of individuals; requires expert integration of isotope geochemistry, geology, and skeletal biology.

A geophysical remote-sensing technique that maps subsurface soil resistivity variations to locate buried features and graves; requires expert knowledge of geophysical instrumentation and data interpretation.

The application of sedimentological and geomorphological analysis to forensic scenes to reconstruct depositional history and detect grave disturbance; requires deep expertise in Quaternary geology and archaeological science.

L4.concept: blunt force vs. sharp force trauma differentiation
L4.brief_rationale: Expert-level classification of skeletal injuries by mechanism — blunt impact versus edged weapon — based on fracture pattern geometry and bone surface characteristics; requires advanced training in skeletal trauma biomechanics.

Controlled outdoor decomposition facilities used to study human taphonomy under variable environmental conditions; expert knowledge of this research tradition informs time-since-death estimation in forensic cases.

Statistical reconstruction of age-at-death and sex distributions within mass-grave populations to infer victim selection patterns and atrocity intent; requires deep expertise in demographic methods and conflict archaeology.

Airborne or ground-based laser scanning to detect subtle surface topography indicating clandestine burial or site disturbance beneath vegetation; requires expert integration of remote sensing and forensic search methodology.

Use of maternally inherited mitochondrial DNA to establish familial relationships and confirm identity of skeletal remains from mass graves; requires expert-level knowledge of population genetics and forensic DNA laboratory practice.
